job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Savannah, GA
pros: Co-workers were wonderful! Benefits were solid- Aetna. Along with base pay, you (LPN) get shift diff for nights and weekends: nights are $4, weekends $8— diffs ARE stackable so your $18 base turns to $30 if you’re a weekend nighter.
cons: Management was scarce and offered little to no support for staff. The staffing crisis peri-pandemic really just left us on our own to cover all patients, no regard for ratios. Make sure you clock out by 7:22 or write down why you’re on the clock late. And clock out for your break- even if you can’t really take it.

pros:
- The pay was very good for this area
- Friendly atmosphere
- Upward mobility for those who want it

If you are in it for the money and/or experience and you have no moral compass, Memorial is the right place for you. They will work you extremely hard, recognize your hard work, make you feel important and special. The facade of a caring, understanding organization is well practiced and expertly executed.
cons:
- Lack of job stability
- Poor leadership
- Lack of transparency/trust
- Very low ethical standards

The leadership at Memorial work for the bottom line, not the employees, not the patients. They pretend to care, which becomes very obvious in the first 6 months. As a former manager at this organization, seeing and hearing the things that are said between HR and leadership was very disturbing. Anyone who pushes for what's right and pushes for change is quickly disposed of. 
As expected in a hospital with low morale and ethical standards, internal growth is as much about unprofessional and often extramarital relationships as it is hard work. Those at the top of their areas usually have a wake of destruction behind them, both personally and professionally.

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Savannah, GA
pros: Critical care staff is excellent. Most of the employees are also great throughout the hospital, so that goes along way with tolerating the cons.
cons:
Onsite HR and IT leave much to be desired.  Everything has to be done through the company HQ HR now that HCA has bought out the hospital.  (The glory days of walking into HR to get something fixed are gone.)   Meanwhile, the IT staff is rude and unhelpful.  

The biggest thing you need to know, though, is that it is all about money at this facility, not patient/family care or employee satisfaction.  I'm convinced that the majority of staff are kept in part time status to avoid giving anyone benefits (even though it would actually be more cost effective to simply higher enough full staff with a modest level of part time staff for auxiliary support).  Likewise, if you are looking for career advancement and there's not a medical doctorate attached to your name, look elsewhere.

pros: Fellow RN's (most, definitely not all) and PCA's were great to work with. The Residents and Attendings of the unit were wonderful. I learned a lot about critical care.
cons: I felt the interim manager cared nothing about the RNs of the unit. All she saw was productivity measures, and it felt as if she cared nothing about the stress we experienced daily. She certainly never made me feel valued as an employee of the unit. We weren't compensated for extra responsibilities such as being the Pediatric Emergency Team RN (while carrying a patient load btw). Also, pretty much never worked less than a 13-13.5hr shift. The vast majority of the time you'll stay too busy to stay on top of charting, so you'll have to stay past handoff to get it all done.

review_title: My position brought a lot of personal satisfaction, but forget about a pat on the back or compensation.
pros: Experience, no matter what it is you want to do, MHUMC can give it to you. This is a teaching hospital & it lives up to that part, however, there can be a downside to that experience as well.
cons: Administration that likes to believe they are keeping the profile of this hospital very high in this community, but doesn't seem to care what their employees think about them. Work with pay raises coming every third year or so without some kind of other help is disheartening--especially to nurses. They need to hire more people that actually do the job of taking care of patients, instead of outside consultants or management.

review_title: It's all about who you know.
pros: The company boasts of being the best paid in the area and has great shift differentials.  Offers a variety of opportunities for advancement
cons: Opportunities for advancement are not based on your contribution or experience, but on who you know.  Pay is great for this area if you work nights or weekends: averaging 3.00-11.35 per hour. Insurance is sub-par

review_title: Memorial is a great place to work.
pros: Memorial provides great opportunity for growth and development if you are willing to step to the plate and take on new challenges. This institution values and invests in patient quality and safety and is therefore in the forefront of this movement.
cons: The challenges that a Team Member faces at Memorial are similar to the challenges that one faces at any health care institution. Operating margins are shrinking on a national scale resulting in health care workers being asked to work more efficiently in a new model of service.

pros: The long-term employees are mostly good people.
cons: This organization is top-heavy. There is a critical lack of communication across the whole place. Salaries are not up to par. There haven't been raises in years. There is a real sense of apathy. There is a revolving door of executives and managers that bring their own spin on how to improve the hospital but usually fail miserably just prolonging the dire straits the hospital is in. And poor financial decisions plague this place.

review_title: Great Company striving for excellent patient care in an ever-changing volatile economic environment.
pros: Memorial Health employees are more like a family and support each other well. Benefits, although not the best, are good when compared with most in todays harsh economy. Management does try to recognize their employees when possible.
cons: Its been 3 years since an annual raise or monetary bonus was provided for employees. The reasons for this are understandable but makes it difficult to provide incentive and makes the future hard to see in a positive light at times.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Savannah, GA
pros:
My favorite thing about working at Memorial was the self scheduling. Only 3 shifts a week were full time, but OT was almost always available. With the self scheduling, I could pick which nights I wanted to work and which ones I could take off. If you're really lucky, you can schedule yourself off for a week straight!
Another pro was working with some of the best nurse's I've ever met. They were extremely compassionate and really helpful to the techs when we were short staffed and had large patient loads.
cons:
Short staffed nearly every night- this created a large patient load for the patient care tech, up to 18 patients each on the floor where I worked. Also, an unfair patient load some nights. One tech could have mostly self care patients, and another might have mostly dependent patients that needed changed every hour or so and bathed. 
Another con I think is the pay. A PCT only makes 10-13 per hour, which isn't much considering the amount of work they do.
Last conversation is having some extremely lazy nurses. If the PCT has a large patient load, the nurse should help out more. But some nights my nurses would just be in the break room all night.

review_title: A staple Non-Profit Plagued by the Politicians and their Self-Interests
pros: A community Hospital with great values. Leadership really does there best to keep morale up even in the darkest of days.
cons: The hospital has sold out to a For-Profit entity out of operational necessity. It was hitting a breaking point where employees were going to not be paid if continuing on the current path. Unfortunately, this deal is more of a benefit for the politicians who orchestrated it, than for the community and the organization itself.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Savannah, GA
pros: The float pool gives me the opportunity to see more of the hospital and broaden my skills as a PCT. I also like the fact that I get to communicate with more people and network a little better.
cons: Not all of the floors are the same when it comes to documentation which can be a little unnerving when it comes to what my job entails. Some floors have checklists that must be marked off each hour and the nurses and techs alternate hours, others don't necessarily have that worked out.

pros:
People
Quality of health care provided
cons:

pros: Great co-workers.  Everyone tried to do their jobs well and worked together.
cons: "Furlough" of staff to make budget - if you had no vacation time, you didn't get paid.  And this was at holiday (Nov/Dec) time. Management hired people that they could blame and fire quickly to save themselves. Lots of personal criticism of staff (looks, clothes, being called stupid) in meetings.

cons: None to speak of, was one of the 2 best laces I have worked in 20+ years as an Rn.
